body:
Honestly Buffet selling even that small stake in Delta helped out the 💎🖐 on my burning puts.

Before COVID media was saying he lost his touch having been outperformed by S&P for the last 5 years. Sitting on a shit ton of cash everyone waiting for him to buy anything and instead he sticks to his guns, says everything is overvalued, and gives money back to shareholders.

Now, especially if we do have another leg down, he has enough cash on hand to acquire companies for half of their market cap 2 months ago. 

He wouldn't have sold Delta shares during the "rally" if he thought it was truly a V shaped recovery. 

I'm with the Oracle. SPY 273P 06/19 picked up today at the highs. Would love to add a 300P if it gets there so keep Brrrring Powell.

author: ghasp
body:
To all those worried: I don't believe that VS meant that the direction of this market depends on today's actions alone. He is saying that there is major support point around SPY 248 - if the market lands above 252, it signals an upward movement to 263 which, if broken, means we are going to 270. If we hit 270, we are going to 300. It would be a sharper "V" shape recovery. 

Tomorrow, or even next week, it is possible to do battle at 248 and win and signal a downward movement towards 231. Here we get into a faster free-fall.

It looks like a bear flag is happening on SPY and it is possible that the movement down is an escalator. If SPY breaks 263, the bear flag is pretty invalid IMO. VIX would mellow and we could reach the goal, but with more sideways trading (drawn out over months).

Correct or comment, please

Edit: could also be other continuation patterns, but this theory more aligns with a quicker drop, like the bear flag...

author: Advice2Anyone
body:
Oh they are Balance sheet =/= stock movement. Look at SPCE as a prime example that is a piece of shit company that hasnt done anything but sit there for yeeeears but a bit of press and people pumping it caused it to fly all over.  


You look at balance sheet to know how much debt the company has and what kinda cash reserves. You can dig deeper to see what kind of debt short term/longterm and when they mature if you really want to. But usually im just browsing to see if any major variations from q to q that would cause a major hedge to change their rating because ultimately the bigger stocks move on bigger trades a person throwing 10k in wont move price, a person throwing 100 billion in will. So thats really what your lookign to do in the short term is beat the hedges to their own valuation. So not looking to see if its good or bad but is it good or bad compared to last year and when was the last time the major hedges updated their valuation and will they before next quarter after that will it trend that way for awhile or will it reverse right away. Its all guessing but the more information the better you can guess.

&#x200B;

Longterm I just invest in Indexes and stocks I believe in and actually use everyday like V and WM etc.

author: AsksAcctQuest
body:
During the recent interview with CNBC (about 6 days ago, 22 mins long, link below) Bill Gates said the infection fatality rate ("IFR") is between 1 to 1.2% percent, and I believe him above all others in this situation -- whether you like him or not, he is an "expert" in this area.

 [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PKg40HX6oUo](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PKg40HX6oUo) 

So, with 28,300 deaths in the U.S. as of this moment, we are likely only at \~2.8 Million infections. This virus is also estimated to have a quite high basic reproduction number ("R0" or "R naught") of about 5.7 per the CDC's best estimate. That means one infected individual -- without any other intervention or behavioral change -- will infect about 6 people during the course of their illness.

However, there is some good news that predicts wearing masks and behavior changes -- e.g. excessive hand washing, distancing -- will significantly reduce the R0. Taleb believes these changes will likely create a convex payoff -- as he likes to say -- which may reduce infection spread by 95%. 

 [https://twitter.com/nntaleb/status/1249296844712218624](https://twitter.com/nntaleb/status/1249296844712218624)

author: BoredMisanthrope
body:
Despite the panic sell off, general sentiment is still greedy as opposed to fearful. I think people do understand that Q2 will take a hit, but I don't think they really have a grasp on what the longer term repercussions are. There's been a lot of talk of V recovery and fast economic snap back, which I think has lulled many into a false sense of confidence. A lot of greed and jumping in, thinking this was a run of the mill overbought correction. There's also probably a lot of new retail investors that don't really know much about the market but saw the fast sell off and think this is a great time to make a fast buck.

I'm not saying a second falling out is a sure thing (though I've bought puts), but I think when you start seeing new money jumping in and getting greedy, that's not indicative of a market that has capitulated and hit a bottom. Usually when people have fully hit the fear button and freak out, that's when you finally reach that oversold bottom. I think when you take the macro into account, factor in some of the issues that were coming up before this crisis took place, I think this new money could get left holding the bag. 

If anything, this crisis might be masking some of the underlying issues that were starting to crop up most of last year. Things weren't all roses, but with this crisis, people are so focused on this (new cases, flattening the curve, etc.) that they've completely lost sight of the long term, which was a highly overbought market that was overdue for a correction. Now you have a market that was overdue for a correction and got hit with a crisis that shut the economy down to a significant degree. Trying to predict when the other shoe drops? Hard to say. The fed isn't going to make that easy. They've completely distorted large portions of the market.

body:
You've already seen pre-announcements from Starbucks and Booking (aka Priceline); neither was good but at least Starbucks had optimistic commentary. So there's two pre-announcements from companies in sectors that have been significantly effected by this and you can see how the stocks have done since.

Broadly, I'd be particularly interested in retail, much of tech (what does the demand picture look like for software companies, for example?), some banks (JPM), travel, card cos (V/MA + the others) and some other odds and ends. I don't plan on buying travel or much of retail for example, but I do want to hear what they have to say. Somewhat curious about restaurants - obviously dine-in is closed, but how much delivery has their been? etc etc.  

Edit: Roku +10% after pre-announce

author: theognis1002
body:
A few points for the bullish real estate sentiment is that the existing inventory out there is extremely low, practically no new housing starts for the non-luxury market, interest rates are still very low, people expect a V-shaped recovery (lol), and real estate is a good hedge against inflation.

The money needs to be shut off for an extended period of time before there are large dislocations in the real estate market. JPM raising borrowing standards is one step in that direction... curious to see if there are more lenders that will follow. I'm hoping prices go down... don't really want it to flourish lol.

author: TrailerParkRide
body: There's a pork shortage on the way. [Smithfield closed their largest plant indefinitely this weekend](https://www.wattagnet.com/articles/40043-smithfield-closes-south-dakota-plant-indefinitely) (produces 5% of the US supply), and there are reports that others might follow suit. Also [there have been labor disputes and protests](https://www.wattagnet.com/articles/39893-perdue-farms-employees-strike-over-covid-19-concerns?v=preview) by meat industry employees that might escalate if covid safety conditions aren't improved. If meat actually starts running out I'm predicting big riots as soon as the weather starts to get warmer. People are already restless, which will get worse whenever the sun finally comes out, and it should only take a whiff of a food shortage to turn the country into 1992 Los Angeles.

author: KimJongUnsTrousers
body: Seeing some interesting parallels with China's stock market. They took a nose dive after lunar new years before us, hit a low on 2/3, then they V-shaped all the way back to pre-Covid heights over a month after pulling all the governmental stops - trillions in fiscal and monetary stimulus + banning short-selling. Every other post here was a FXI put holder complaining about the most manipulated market in the world and fuck CCP. Every response was - don't bet against the CCP, supply and lock-downs don't matter, brrrrrr. Then, they made a new low and cratered with us in March - a perfect bear market down wave until they set a new low 3/23 (smaller drop than us, only 13%). If we follow their pattern, we have about a week left of this rally.

author: JustinUti
body:
My opinion on todays market movement:

 

Last two weeks investors have moved into tech as a "safe space", which is reflected in its gains obviously over the last couple weeks. Sunday, Cuomo announced that NYC hospitalizations have been steadily decreasing over the last 14 days and virus deaths hit a one-month low. The greatest outbreak center in the US is slowing down and investors see this. This signals to investors that the virus-curve is flattening and we are on our way to recovery. So in the short term (1-2 months) we will be fine. What remains to be seen are the long term effects the shutdown will have on the economy and business.

 

Today, you are seeing investors be more optimistic about the market in the short term w/ a near-term recovery (V-shaped) and are moving money back from Tech into the more traditional sectors which explains why tech is down today but SPY is up bigly. If techs earnings are within the pessimistic expectations of wall street, we will keep mooning.

 

TLDR: If you are a bear, you better be fucking hedged.

author: chocoboat
body:
I made a similar mistake, not at the bottom but close enough to it. I was convinced March 26 was a dead cat bounce, felt confident in the next few days as it started to slide again, but started to consider if I should jump back in at about the same level I sold at, to make sure I wouldn't regret my choice to sell.

No, I felt the economic data looks too ugly, surely it's going down more before any real recovery... and then it zoomed. Plenty of anxiety and disgust with myself in the past few days and now I have to deal with deciding when to get back in (if I do it now will it drop right back, taking the same losses twice? if I don't is it headed to the moon?)

This confusion is real. There shouldn't be a v shaped recovery from mass unemployment and a worldwide recession, and one this quick just blows my mind. Maybe it won't hold? I honestly have no clue whatsoever. Right now I have no choice to count this as an expensive life lesson, I was 100% certain it would dive well under 20k for a while, or at absolute best hover at 20k, with 0% chance of things skyrocketing up as the pandemic gets worse and worse. I'll never do anything but hold long term through a bad situation again.

The anxiety is still with me though, and I don't know how long it'll take for it to wear off. There's no choice to accept what's done is done but it's a tough pill to swallow. I try to look at the positives... I'm still more than double where I was 10 years ago, and would have been happy with that if you told me back then. Other people have far worse problems lately, thank god I'm not struggling to breathe with the virus right now.

But man, it hurts to know that I caused this for myself.

author: Gypsiee
body:
Because "Stocks" are not cheap.   But certain companies absolutely are going to bounce back to 12 year high levels.  

Like, I don't care what you can buy GameStop for right now, it's too much.  But Microsoft dipping 10%?  I'll take that.   

A companies valuation is based on their expected revenues and growth in the long term considering their current positions.   Stocks went up for 12 years because businesses expanded, added assets, grew customer based.  

The fundamentals of something like VISA never changed, I'll buy it 30% down from peak.   That's "Cheap".

author: sellallporkbellies
body: What a horrible way to phrase this. What OP should really be saying is "obviously a v-shaped recovery is imminent, but are you concerned by the minor blips of record unemployment and near-zero economic activity?"

author: KeyWaste
body:
At your age, don't focus on dividends.  You want rock solid growth.  There will be a few dividends in the high quality portfolio (if automatic reinvesting is available for a quality stock, do it)
Coke, Pfizer, Proctor & Gamble, Visa, Microsoft.  These are the kind of names you want

author: sryu4
body: Futures are meaningless for bears right now. For bulls they are looking for every tiny bit of green to justify that maybe the economy is going to be ok and this is going to be a v shape recovery. The bull banter here is obvious, they are trying to trap retarded noobs into buying their bags. Retail investors are unwittingly propping this market up via FOMO. No one here who has traded longer than 2 months thinks this is a v shape recovery. When the bears finally get a win it's going to be a huge fucking win and new investors are going to be holding a shit ton of useless calls and stocks. Risk to reward of holding puts right now is better than holding calls.

body: The Market getting that V shaped recovery while the real economy is stuck in that L shape.

author: Aesthetikal
body:
Daily life of bear:

1. Wake up in Wendy's parking lot 
2. Give $10 blowies to random homeless dudes to fund SPY puts
3. Scream "Imagine thinking we've already bottomed!" "Wait till unemployment numbers!" and "V shaped recovery is a myth!" all day long 
4. Get fucked
5. Repeat

author: rthrowabc
body:
V-S really appreciate the knowledge we are gaining here. Come what may, your posts help us learn a lot of course we need to spend time reading up. By helping us learn you will help people make educated bet. A bet is a bet but learning is the most important thing. 

We can fail 9 times for that one success. See Bezos quote below. People don’t give up and don’t focus on a short term gain or loss. Take all of this as a learning experience this only makes you stronger and smarter. What V-S is teaching here is invaluable. 

“Bezos says nine times out of ten, you're going to fail. But every once in while, you'll hit a home run that in business terms is more like 1,000 runs. "Given a ten percent chance of a 100 times payoff, you should take that bet every time,"

author: welcometa_erf
body: What’s a company worth if Main Street can’t afford its products? This is what the market hasn’t “priced in.” We’re staring down the barrel of a global depression not seen since the 1930s and people are thinking now is the time to buy. Capitulation hasn’t even materialized. People see stocks only go up, but what they fail to notice is the intraday volatility is extremely bearish. It’s not even May yet. The only way for a V-shaped economic recovery is a vaccine. That’s at least a year to two years away.

author: RayCashIsTrashDalio
body: bulls got slaughtered during the crash. bears got slaughtered during the V shaped recovery. theta gang got slaughtered by the volatility. in the end everyone fucking lost. no retail trader is going to last or has lasted over 6 months in this rigged market. :|

author: CptTonyStark
body:
Glad I didn’t end up getting AMZN 5/1 2600c and V 5/1 185c that I was thinking long and hard about. After watching NFLX INTC and AMD, I realized earnings are just a gamble and decided against betting on them. 

I’m temporarily quitting trading to focus on other hobbies like guitar and getting 6 pack abs, I will be back in a month or so. I made 17k in profits in 2 months thanks to this sub and I have left 1k in my RH to start over when I return. 

This sub has helped me get through some tough times and I’ll always love all of you tards. Thank you all for everything, I hope u enjoy lots of tendies!
